message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Chronic pelvic pain during sexual intercourse, new onset vaginal discharge, and cervical motion tenderness suggest pelvic inflammatory disease, which is commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections. The patient’s sexual history and smoking further increase her risk of developing pelvic inflammatory disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Chronic pelvic pain, yellowish vaginal discharge, tenderness on bimanual exam, and cervical motion tenderness suggest pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). The patient's sexual history increases her risk for sexually transmitted infections, which can lead to PID. Ectopic pregnancy can cause pelvic pain and vaginal bleeding, but it is not associated with yellowish vaginal discharge or cervical motion tenderness. Bacterial vaginosis can cause a yellowish discharge and a fishy odor on whiff test, but it is not associated with pelvic pain or cervical motion tenderness. A urinary tract infection typically causes dysuria, frequency, and urgency, but not pelvic pain or vaginal discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The chronic pelvic pain, painful intercourse, and multiple sexual partners suggest pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). The yellowish vaginal discharge also supports this diagnosis. The tender adnexa and uterus with cervical motion tenderness on exam also point towards PID.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s chronic pelvic pain, painful intercourse, new onset yellowish vaginal discharge, and tender adnexa and uterus with cervical motion tenderness points towards Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID). Ectopic Pregnancy usually presents with severe sudden onset abdominal pain and bleeding. Bacterial vaginosis may cause discharge, but it does not cause pelvic pain. Urinary tract infection may cause pain or burning during urination, but it does not cause pelvic pain or vaginal discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, especially the chronic pelvic pain and new onset yellowish vaginal discharge, suggest pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Bacterial vaginosis is a possibility due to the high number of sexual partners, but the negative whiff test and elevated vaginal pH make it less likely. Ectopic pregnancy and urinary tract infection are unlikely given the symptoms and physical exam findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, especially chronic pelvic pain and adnexal tenderness on exam, suggest pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). The new onset of yellowish vaginal discharge is also a common symptom of PID. Bacterial vaginosis may cause yellowish discharge, but it would not cause pelvic pain. Ectopic pregnancy would cause abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding, which are not mentioned in the patient’s presentation. Urinary tract infection may cause fever and increased urinary frequency, but it would not cause pelvic pain or adnexal tenderness on exam.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The chronic pelvic pain and tenderness on bimanual exam suggest Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID), which is commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia and gonorrhea. The new onset yellowish vaginal discharge also supports this diagnosis. The negative whiff test rules out bacterial vaginosis. Ectopic pregnancy is not likely as there is no mention of missed menstrual periods, and urinary tract infection would not cause pelvic pain or tenderness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The chronic pelvic pain, sexual pain, and yellowish discharge suggest Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID), which is often caused by sexually transmitted infections. The tenderness on bimanual exam, cervical motion tenderness, and elevated temperature also support the diagnosis of PID. The other options are less likely based on the symptoms presented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Chronic pelvic pain, painful intercourse, yellowish vaginal discharge, and multiple sexual partners suggest a diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease. The bimanual exam and cervical motion tenderness further support this diagnosis. The other options are less likely given the patient’s symptoms and exam findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with chronic pelvic pain, yellowish discharge, and tender adnexa and uterus with cervical motion tenderness. These are classic symptoms of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID), which is most commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections like chlamydia and gonorrhea. The fact that the patient has had multiple sexual partners and does not use contraception also increases her risk for PID. Ectopic pregnancy and urinary tract infection do not present with these symptoms, and bacterial vaginosis may be associated with a positive Whiff test and a vaginal pH greater than 4.5, but does not usually cause pelvic pain.
